ProbeAction.QueryStatement: SELECT GlobalInitPercentage, LinkStatus, LinkStatusDescription, Site1, Site1Status, Site1ToSite2GlobalState, Site2, Site2Status, Site2ToSite1GlobalState, Site2ToSite1SiteState, SiteName1, SiteName2 FROM SMS_ReplicationLinkSummary WHERE Site1 = '$Config/ParentSite$' AND Site2 = '$Config/ChildSite$'

SELECT AlertState, DateAlertStateModified, DateCreated, Deletable, Enabled, FeatureArea, FeatureGroup, ID, InstanceNameParam1, InstanceNameParam2, LastModifiedBy, MonitoredByScom, Name, ObjectTypeID, OccurrenceCount, ParameterValues, Severity, SkipUntil, TypeID, TypeInstanceID FROM SMS_Alert WHERE TypeId = "$Config/TypeId$" AND TypeInstanceID = "$Config/TypeInstanceId$"

SELECT ProxyName, ProxyEnabled, Port, ProxyPollingInterval, ProxyCertPath, PeriodicCatalogUpdateEnabled, PeriodicCatalogUpdateSchedule, LastCatalogUpdateCompletion, CatalogWatermark, SCOURL, ProxyState, LastSCOReturnCode, LastCatalogUpdateRequest, CategoryChangeCount, SoftwareTitlesChangeCount, CPUChangeCount, HWReqChangeCount, RelevancyOptOut, SiteCode FROM SMS_AIProxy WHERE ProxyName = '$Config/ProxyName$'

SELECT AlertState, DateAlertStateModified, DateCreated, Deletable, Enabled, FeatureArea, FeatureGroup, ID, InstanceNameParam1, InstanceNameParam2, LastModifiedBy, MonitoredByScom, Name, ObjectTypeID, OccurrenceCount, ParameterValues, Severity, SkipUntil, TypeID, TypeInstanceID FROM SMS_EPAlert WHERE TypeId = "$Config/TypeId$" AND TypeInstanceID = "$Config/TypeInstanceId$"

SELECT AlertState, DateAlertStateModified, DateCreated, Deletable, Enabled, FeatureArea, FeatureGroup, ID, InstanceNameParam1, InstanceNameParam2, LastModifiedBy, MonitoredByScom, Name, ObjectTypeID, OccurrenceCount, ParameterValues, Severity, SkipUntil, TypeID, TypeInstanceID FROM SMS_CHAlert WHERE TypeId = "$Config/TypeId$" AND TypeInstanceID = "$Config/TypeInstanceId$"

DisplayString.Name: MCM WSUS Synchronization Failed Monitor
DisplayString.Description: This monitor identifies when a synchronization of the software update point has failed. The software update point synchronization process involves getting the latest update catalog into WSUS, and synching the metadata into the Configuration Manager database. If synchronization fails at any step, then your ability to measure and remediate compliance for the most current published updates will be compromised.

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog Web Site Point Availability Monitor

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog Web Site Point Not Available
DisplayString.Description: The {0} on computer {1} is not available.

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog Web Server Monitor
DisplayString.Description: This monitor checks that the application catalog web server is responding to HTTP requests.

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog Web Server HTTP Not Responding
DisplayString.Description: The Application Catalog web server on computer {0} is not responding to HTTP requests.

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog IIS Configuration Monitor
DisplayString.Description: This monitor checks for the correct IIS configuration for the Configuration Manager's Application Catalog server role.

DisplayString.Name: MCM Application Catalog IIS Not Configured Correctly

DisplayString.Description: This monitor checks the availability status of IIS services.

DisplayString.Name: MCM IIS Service Not Running on Application Catalog Web Site Point
DisplayString.Description: The {0} service on computer {1} is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of Asset Intelligence Point synchronization. It generates an alert if the Asset Intelligence data cannot be successfully synchronized.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The synchronization fails due to one of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A Network error
The catalog service is unavailable

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Provide the error code from log to the Configuration Manager administrator for troubleshooting.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: The Asset Intelligence catalog will not be updated. This could impact the category and license matching for Asset Intelligence reports.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of the Asset Intelligence Synchronization Point. The site periodically updates a registry key that indicates its health. The management pack monitors the registry key to show the health status.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Asset Intelligence Synchronization Point is not functioning.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can provide the error code from the error log to the Configuration Manager administrator for troubleshooting.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of Out of band service point. The site role periodically updates a registry key to indicate its healthy status. Management pack monitors the registry key to show the healthy status on SCOM. Please list the possible cause of the failure and the resolution.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Out of band service point is not functioning well

maml:para.maml:ui: Reinstall the Out of band service point

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Out of Band Service Point (OOBSP) is not able to connect to Enrollment Point.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Enrollment Point URL (can be retrieved from amtopmgr.log) is not accessible because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) is not installed on Enrollment Point
The enrollment Point has been removed
The Https port of the enrollment point machine has not been binding to the right certificate

maml:section.maml:para: Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) is not installed on the Out of Band Service Point.
The Out of Band Service Point and the Enrollment Point are not mutually trusted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check if WCF is active on enrollment point machine and its https port has been binding to right cert, and then re-install Enrollment Point manually. Verify if the Enrollment Point URL is accessible.
Make sure WCF is installed on the Out of Band Service Point.
Verify the Swap certificate success, if not, you may need to manually copy the cert. Ensure that:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The OOBSP Site System Identification certificate is in the ES trusted people certificate store
The certificate binding to the https port of the enrollment point machine is in the OOBSP trusted people certificate store.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the application installation status on the Configuration Manager client. If an application fails to install on the client using the Operations Manager agent the monitor generates an alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The possible root cause may be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The content of the package is missing or corrupt.
Failure to download the content from distribution points.
The executable file referred to by the program command-line does not exist.
A failure exit code was returned while installing the application.
Check the Configuration Manager console to see if the content is successfully deployed to the distribution points. Try to redeploy the content to the distribution points.
Check the command-line used and ensure it refers to the correct executable file.
Check the returned error code to figure out the root cause of installation failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of application catalog web service point. The site role periodically updates a registry key to indicate its health status. Management pack monitors the registry key to show the health status on SCOM.
This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

This monitor is the same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If the W3SVC monitor is already enabled, this monitor can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks that the application catalog web service is responding to HTTP requests. It raises alerts if the web service fails to respond to an HTTP or HTTPS request.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following are possible causes:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The application catalog service is not started or not responding.
Internet Information Services (IIS) is not responding.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Manually restart the W3SVC service on the application catalog web service point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks for the correct IIS configuration for the Configuration Manager's Application Catalog web service role. It raises alerts if the configuration failed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The web.config file for the application catalog web site is inaccessible due to restricted file permissions.
The web.config file is corrupted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Reinstall the application catalog web site point role.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.
This monitor is as same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If that monitor is enabled, this one can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects the average number of updates per minute written by the WSUS sync manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager backup process is responsible for backing up the Configuration Manager site server and site database. This process failed due to an error condition. Recovery from backup will not be possible until this issue is resolved and the backup process is rerun.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: There are many reasons the Configuration Manager backup process can fail. Each of these failures has a unique Configuration Manager status message ID, which is raised as the error state ID for this alert. To determine the possible causes for the current failure, use the Status Message Viewer within the Configuration Manager console to locate the status message with a status message ID that corresponds with the error state ID of this alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The possible solutions for this alert vary based on the specific error that occurred. To determine the possible solutions for the current failure, use the Status Message Viewer within the Configuration Manager console to locate the status message with a status message ID that corresponds with the error state ID of this alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: To manage the client notification channel, the client notification manager must initialize successfully on a primary site. Client notification will not work if the client notification manager fails to initialize.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Client notification manager failed to initialize.
Check bgbmgr.log on the site server for more information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: To manage notification channel, Configuration Manager client notification requires Systems Management Server (SMS) Notification Manager to initialize successfully on a primary site. Client notification will not work if Microsoft SQL Server Service Broker that is used by the SMS Notification Manager is disabled.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: SQL Server Service Broker used by the notification manager is disabled.
Check bgbmgr.log on the primary site.
Enable SQL Server Service Broker in the site database.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager client cannot connect to the Client Notification Server on management point by using HTTP.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check if the Configuration Manager Client Notification Proxy Pool in Internet Information Services (IIS) application pools is stopped. If the Client Notification Proxy Pool is stopped, start it.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The recommended channel for a client to establish a connection to the Client Notification Server is using a TCP port. However, if Windows Firewall (or other firewall software) is enabled on a Client Notification Server it may be configured to disallow such communication.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Windows Firewall blocks client connections to the TCP port that is used by client notification.
Check the bgbserver.log log file on the management point for more information.
Review Windows Firewall configuration for the TCP port used by client notification. If required, add an exception rule for this port, either for dllhost.exe (recommended) or for the entire server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: To receive the connection requests sent by clients, the Client Notification Server must successfully initialize on a management point. Client notification will not work if the Client Notification Server fails to initialize.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: COM objects inside the Client Notification Server failed to initialize.
Check bgbserver.log on the management point for more information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Client Notification Server on the management point will initialize the TCP listener to accept the connection request sent by the Configuration Manager clients. Sometimes the Client Notification Server fails to initialize the TCP listener.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Another application is listening on the same TCP port that is used by Client Notification Server.
Check bgbserver.log on the management point for more information.
Close any other application that is listening on the port that is used by Client Notification Server on the management point.
Configure the Client Notification Server to use another port.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager continuously monitors the health of the connectivity between parent and child Configuration Manager sites and parent and child SQL Server databases. This confirms that replication is active across sites within a Configuration Manger hierarchy. These checks occur regularly to ensure that global data (e.g., application metadata and configuration items) is synchronized across the site server hierarchy for and up the hierarchy for site data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Any number of causes will cause a failure of replication between Configuration Manger parent and child sites:
• Database machine certificate is invalid.
• Database service broker certificate is invalid.
• SQL Port defined in configuration manager is not correct.
• SQL Service Broker port is incorrect.
• SQL Port is not open on the firewall.
• Cannot use the specified account to connect to SQL server.
• The disk space on SQL server is insufficient.
• SQL Server service is down.
• SQL Server service broker is down.
• SMSEXEC service is down.
• Network connectivity between Configuration Manager Sites is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: System administrators for both SQL Server and Configuration Manager as well as the network administrator should discuss options available to remedy the replication issues among Configuration Manager sites. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager keeps continuously monitors the health of connectivity between parent and child sites and parent and child SQL Servers to make sure that replication is active across sites within a Configuration Manger hierarchy. These checks occur regularly to ensure that data is synchronized across the hierarchy among site servers for global data (e.g., application metadata and configuration items) and up the hierarchy for site data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Any number of causes will cause a failure of replication between Configuration Manger parent and child sites:
• Database machine certificate is invalid.
• Database service broker certificate is invalid.
• SQL Port defined in configuration manager is not correct.
• SQL Service Broker port is incorrect.
• SQL Port is not open on the firewall.
• Cannot use the specified account to connect to SQL server.
• The disk space on SQL server is insufficient.
• SQL Server service is down.
• SQL Server service broker is down.
• SMSEXEC service is down.
• Network connectivity between Configuration Manager Sites is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: System administrators for both SQL Server and Configuration Manager as well as the network administrator should discuss options available to remedy the replication issues among Configuration Manager sites. You may also check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager keeps continuously monitors the health of connectivity between parent and child sites and parent and child SQL Servers to make sure that replication is active across sites within a Configuration Manger hierarchy. These checks occur regularly to ensure that data is synchronized across the hierarchy among site servers for global data (e.g., application metadata and configuration items) and up the hierarchy for site data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Any number of causes will cause a failure of replication between Configuration Manger parent and child sites:
• Database machine certificate is invalid.
• Database service broker certificate is invalid.
• SQL Port defined in configuration manager is not correct.
• SQL Service Broker port is incorrect.
• SQL Port is not open on the firewall.
• Cannot use the specified account to connect to SQL server.
• The disk space on SQL server is insufficient.
• SQL Server service is down.
• SQL Server service broker is down.
• SMSEXEC service is down.
• Network connectivity between Configuration Manager Sites is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: System administrators for both SQL Server and Configuration Manager as well as the network administrator should discuss options available to remedy the replication issues among Configuration Manager sites. You may also check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager checks the client active/inactive status of the specified collection. If the client didn’t communicate with Configuration Manager for a period of time set in the Configuration Manager console, the status of the client becomes “inactive. “
For more details, view the client check node in the Configuration Manager console.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The percentage of active clients in the specified collection is lower than the selected threshold.
Check the clients to figure out the reason of inactivity.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager checks the client status of the specified collection. The client health check pass rate should be higher than the selected threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
For more details, view the client check node in the Configuration Manager console to see the root cause of the failure.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The percentage of clients that passed the health check is lower than the selected threshold.
Check the root cause of the client health check failure and take appropriate action to fix the issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager tries to remediate clients that failed to pass the health check to fix the known issues. Configuration Manager generates an alert if the remediation success rate is lower than the selected threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
For more details, view the client check node in the Configuration Manager console.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The percentage of clients that were successfully remediated in the specified collection is lower than the selected threshold.
Check the clients to figure out the reason of failure.
Reinstall the Configuration Manager client.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager supports storing the content on the cloud-based distribution point. Configuration Manager monitors storage usage and generates an alert when you reach the storage quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:listItem.maml:para: You have reached the storage quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can use either of the following solutions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Purchase more storage.
Check the content on the cloud-based distribution point and delete unnecessary content.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager supports storing the content on the cloud-based distribution point. Configuration Manager monitors storage usage and generates an alert when you reach the storage quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: You have reached the storage quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can use either of the following solutions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Purchase more storage.
Check the content on the cloud-based distribution point and delete unnecessary content.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager monitors the volume of data transferred off Windows Azure and generates an alert when the volume reaches the transfer quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:listItem.maml:para: You have reached the transfer quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can use either of the following solutions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Purchase more transfer quota bandwidth.
Check cloud-based distribution point and limit the client downloads if necessary.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager monitors the volume of data transferred off Windows Azure and generates an alert when the volume reaches the transfer quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:listItem.maml:para: You have reached the transfer quota on the cloud-based distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can use either of the following solutions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Purchase more transfer quota bandwidth.
Check cloud-based distribution point and limit the client downloads if necessary.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This is an aggregation monitor of component health status. Check the unit monitors for root causes and resolutions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the component of the component monitor on the site server role is not healthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following may be the cause for this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The component manager is not running.
The SMS executive service is not running.
There may be connectivity issues with the site system database server.
There may be insufficient permissions of site systems accessing these components.
Use the Configuration Manager services manager to restart and monitor the components that are inactive
Check for environmental changes to the site system servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS_Executive detected that an auto started component stopped unexpectedly.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is experiencing a severe problem that caused it to stop unexpectedly.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Use the Configuration manager services manager to restart and monitor the components that are inactive.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the component of component status summarizer on site server role is not healthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following may be the cause for this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The component manager is not running.
The SMS executive service is not running.
There may be connectivity issues with the site system database server.
There may be a high volume of client status updates.
There may be a high volume of discovery updates or additions.
Check that all the components are running.
Check for environmental changes such as permissions that affect your site system servers.
Check disk space availability.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: You can define the target compliance % (SLA) for each baseline deployment. You can also define the date and time for when to evaluate this threshold upon deployment. If the % of computers or user compliance is less then target compliance % then an alert will be generated.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The % of computers or user compliance is less then target compliance % you defined.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the baseline deployment status based on the number of assets impacted.
Enable remediation to enforce these settings.
Change the compliance target.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Package Transfer Manager failed to send files to the destination server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The distribution point might not be accessible to the Distribution Manager running on the site server.
The Distribution Manager does not have sufficient rights to the computer.
The site server account does not have the required permissions.
The distribution point server might not be connected to the LAN.
The share on the distribution point server might not be accessible.
The network load might be too high.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If users are currently accessing the package files on the distribution point, disconnect the users first and configuration manager will automatically retry.
Verify that distribution point server is connected to the LAN and functioning properly.
Verify that the share is visible and that the site server machine account or site system connection account has the necessary permissions to access the share.
Verify that the network is not overloaded. Verify that you can move large amounts of data across the network.

Make sure the site server machine account or the site system connection account has full access to the directory on the destination site server and the destination site server has sufficient free disk space.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the database connection between the ConfigMgr site server and the Site database server. It generates an alert when the site server fails to connect to the site database server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: There are many possible root causes, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Site database server is offline.
The network between the site server and the site database server is offline.
The database credentials used by the site server are expired or incorrect.
The database credentials used by the site server do not have sufficient permissions.
The database connection configuration is incorrect.
View SQL Server Alerts to check the status of the database server.
Check the network between site server and site database server.
Check the credentials used by site server.
Check whether the account has permissions.
Check the database connection configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The database machine certificate is used provide authentication and to encrypt communications between most site system roles or the provider and the database. It is used for direct SQL Server calls to the database instance defined for that site. When the certificate is valid, normal authenticated and encrypted communication between the site system roles or the provider and the SQL Server is encrypted using this certificate. However, once the certificate is invalid, the communications between the site system roles or the provider and the SQL Server is not allowed. The database machine certificate is automatically created during installation of the Configuration Manager site server if a machine certificate does not already exist – it expires 30 years after the original creation. A database machine certificate could already exist because it was originally created through a corporate PKI dictated by corporate policy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The database machine certificate becomes invalid in one of several ways:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The database machine certificate is manually deleted from the certificate store.
The database machine certificate has expired.
The security access for the database machine certificate has been altered such that Configuration Manager or the SQL Server is unable to access the certificate

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration manager automatically corrects this scenario by recreating a self-signed certificate, whether or not the original invalid certificate was created by PKI or Configuration Manager. The expiration date for the newly created self-signed certificate is 30 years after the creation date. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the site server fails to execute a maintenance task.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host is stopped or is not responding.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it is stopped or is not responding, restart the service.
Check IIS health.
Check network connectivity to the site system database server, along with certificate issues that may exist (check in the administration console database replication node under monitoring).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The rule collects the discovery data record (DDR) generation rate by group discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The rule collects the discovery data record (DDR) generation rate by system discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The rule collects the discovery data record (DDR) generation rate by user discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

This monitor is the same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If the W3SVC monitor is already enabled, this monitor can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Distribution Manager cannot access the Network Abstraction Layer (NAL).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the Distribution Manager cannot access the NAL due to an unexpected failure within the NAL.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Use the Service Manager to enable logging for the Distribution Manager. Then, investigate the log file for specific NAL errors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Distribution Manager requires that Internet Information Services (IIS) base components be installed on the local Configuration Manager site server in order to configure the ports. The Distribution Manager also requires that IIS Web services be installed on the distribution point server that has to support Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS). Verify that IIS base components are installed on the local Configuration Manager site server and that IIS Web services are installed on the distribution point server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: IIS is not installed and running on the distribution point.
There are problems with the network connection to the distribution point.
Domain Name System (DNS) problems can also prevent the Distribution Manager from remotely connecting to the distribution point to configure ports in IIS.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks if the Microsoft Configuration Manager Site server can successfully configure the Active Directory for AMT provisioning

maml:listItem.maml:para: This monitor checks the ConfigMgr reported status from the registry. These keys are located at

The Severity registry value determines the health state. 0 or 1 is Healthy, while 2 or 3 is unhealthy. You can review the Time of last report and if this is very old, you can consider resetting the Severity to 0 in the registry to set the monitor back to healthy, if you are sure the component is working in MCM. Sometimes these status message driven registry entries do not get updated back to healthy.
This monitor uses the following registry location: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\SMS\Operations Management\Components\SMS_EN_ADSERVICE_MONITOR\CAFD8C35-08B6-4772-9101-B1B220CBA044
The Site Server does not have permission to create AD machine account or join security group.
The credentials used by the Site server to connect to the Domain Controller are incorrect.
The Domain Controller is not functioning correctly.
Check that the Domain Controller is running properly.
Check that Site Server has permissions to create AD machine account and join account to Security Group.
Check that the credentials used by the Site Server to connect to the Domain Controller are correct.
New AMT machines cannot be provisioned.
Provisioned AMT machines cannot renew their credentials

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of the enrollment point. The site role periodically updates a registry key to indicate its health status. The management pack monitors the registry key to show the health status.
This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

This monitor is the same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If the W3SVC monitor is already enabled, this monitor can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks if the Enrollment Point is able to request certificates from the Certification Authority (CA) on behalf of the mobile device or AMT client. It produces an alert if the Enrollment Point cannot request the certificate from the CA.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Users allowed to enroll might not have permission to enroll for the CA template configured in the enrollment profile.
The Certificate Template configured on the CA has incorrect settings (for example wrong key length)
The CA is not functioning correctly.
The security group for the AMT client account does not have Enroll permissions.
Check that the credentials used to communicate with the CA server are correct.
Check that the Certification Authority is running properly.
Check the failed certificate request on the CA.
Check the security groups for the AMT account to ensure the Enroll permissions are setup correctly.
New mobile devices cannot enroll to Configuration Manager.
Enrolled mobile devices will not be able to renew their certificates.
New AMT machines cannot be provisioned.
Provisioned AMT machines cannot renew their certificates.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This "Revoke Certificate Failure Detection Rule" detects the failure when an Enrollment Point fails to revoke a certificate.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Enrollment Point failed to revoke the certificate of a mobile device that was recently deleted or wiped.
The Enrollment Point failed to revoke the certificate of AMT clients when they are not provisioned.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Make sure that the Certification Authority (CA) that issued the certificate is running and can be contacted by the enrollment point machine.
Verify that the enrollment point machine has management rights on that particular certification authority.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks if the Enrollment Point responds to HTTP requests. You get an alert if the Enrollment Point is not responding to HTTP requests from the Enrollment Proxy point.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Enrollment Point is down.
There are issues with communication between the Enrollment Proxy Point and the Enrollment Point.
Ensure that the Enrollment Point is operating.
Check the connectivity between the Enrollment Point and the Enrollment Proxy point.
New mobile devices cannot enroll to Microsoft Configuration Manager.
Enrolled mobile devices will not be able to renew their certificates.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.
This monitor is as same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If that monitor is enabled, this one can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks that the Enrollment Point can connect to the SQL Server database. It produces an alert if the connection cannot be made.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SQL Server service is not working.
The credentials used to connect to the SQL Server database are incorrect.
Manually restart the SQL server service.
Ensure that the credentials used to communicate with the SQL Server database are correct.
New mobile devices cannot enroll to Configuration Manager.
Enrolled mobile devices will not be able to renew their certificates.
New AMT machines cannot be provisioned.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of Enrollment proxy point. The site role periodically updates a registry key to indicate its health status. Management pack monitors the registry key to show the health status on SCOM.
This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

This monitor is the same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If the W3SVC monitor is already enabled, this monitor can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.
This monitor is as same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If that monitor is enabled, this one can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Exchange Server Connector connects to the Exchange server to discover and manage mobile devices.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Credentials used to connect to the Exchange server are invalid.
Credentials used to connect to the Exchange server do not have sufficient permissions.
The Configuration Manager site server fails to connect to the Exchange server.
Check the network connection between the Configuration Manager site server and the Exchange server.
Check the credentials used to connect to Exchange server to make sure they are valid and have sufficient permissions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of Fallback status point. The site role periodically updates a registry key to indicate its healthy status based on Internet Information Server availability. It raises an alert if the web service fails to respond to an HTTP request.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following are possible causes:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Fallback status point role is not started or not responding.
Internet Information Server (IIS) is not responding.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Manually restart the W3SVC service on the Fallback status point and make sure the Fallback status point role is started.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: SMS_MP_FILE_DISPATCH_MANAGER is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the Configuration Manager management point file dispatch manager component within its expected interval. This can be due to high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the Mdfdm.log file in the [Configuration Manager installation folder]\Logs folder for further information.
Check whether the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Check whether a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The management point File Dispatch Manager that is running on the management point "%1" cannot connect to site server "%2".

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The site server is turned off, not connected to the network, or not functioning properly.
Network problems are preventing the management point file dispatch manager from properly accessing the site server.
The account that is used to connect the management point to the site server might be locked out or might not have needed permissions.
Verify that the site server is turned on, connected to the network, and functioning properly.
Investigate and correct any problems with your network.
Check that the account is not locked out and that it has needed permissions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Distribution Manager copies the content of the package to the distribution point. It creates the distribution point share and package content folder on the NTFS drive with the largest amount of free space on the on the distribution point. It automatically chooses the next drive when the first one has insufficient space for the next new package or for an update of the package.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This alert is raised due to insufficient free disk space on the distribution point.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Free up disk space on the site server.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Use the Disk Cleanup Utilities provided by the operating system to free up disk space on the NTFS drive on the site server.
Delete compressed copies of the package content on distribution points.
Delete unnecessary packages from the Configuration Manager console.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.
This monitor is as same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If that monitor is enabled, this one can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS_INBOX_MANAGER is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the Inbox Manager component within its expected interval. This can be caused by high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS_INBOX_MONITOR is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the SMS_INBOX_MONITOR component within its expected interval. This can be caused by high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check that the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Check that a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager LAN sender cannot connect to the remote site. If there are no other senders configured to connect to the remote site, there will be no communication from this site to the remote site until this condition is resolved. Communication can still be received from the remote site.

If the remote site is a parent site, this site cannot send any inventory or status messages up the site hierarchy. If the remote site is a child site, this site cannot send any package information or site configuration requests down the hierarchy.
The LAN sender automatically retries the connection and send operations.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The remote site server is not functioning properly or is not connected to the network.

The share \\<ServerName>\SMS_SITE on the remote site server is not accessible. With advanced security enabled, the local site server computer account must be a member of the Site-to-Site Connection group on the remote site server.
Network conditions are preventing connectivity.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: This alert is best handled by Configuration Manager administrators.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager generates an alert when it detects a malware on a single device in a collection.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Configuration Manager detected a malware on a device.
Check the Endpoint Protection dashboard and reports in the Configuration Manager console for detailed information about the device and the detected malware.
Remove the malware.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager generates an alert when it detects that the percentage of devices infected with malware in a specific collection exceeds the preset threshold.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Configuration Manager console.
Navigate to the collection and open its properties.
In the properties dialog, click the Alert tab.
Modify the Malware outbreak threshold.
Configuration Manager detected that multiple devices in a collection are infected with malware.
Check the Endpoint Protection dashboard and reports in the Configuration Manager console for detailed information about the devices and the detected malware.
Remove the malware.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager management point is currently unhealthy. It has failed to respond to an active policy or authentication request.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the management point has failed to process a heartbeat policy or authentication request from MP_CONTROL_MANAGER.

If a Management Point has been configured to use a database other than its site database the Management Point health check will indicate unhealthy if the data has not been replicated or has been replicated incorrectly.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Verify that the SMS Agent service is running.
Check the MPControl.log file and component status for MP_CONTROL_MANAGER for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor identifies the Configuration Manager management point’s basic online status, by sending and receiving a basic HTTP request to the management point. The component MP_CONTROL_MANAGER monitors those requests. When a management point is online, it can accept incoming communications from client computers. When the management point is offline, client computers cannot communicate their status, inventory, or state information to the Configuration Manager site. When the management point is offline or in a failed state, client computers cannot make inquiries of the management point to locate content such as software or software updates, and cannot locate key data or system information provided by the management point. When a client computer cannot communicate with any management point, it cannot be actively managed by Microsoft Configuration Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The MP_CONTROL_MANAGER component or a management point component is not responding to HTTP requests.
A heartbeat has not been received from the management point control manager component within its expected interval. This can be due to:
High system and Configuration Manager processing loads.
An extended wait on a request.
A deadlock on a shared resource.
A dependent service required by the management point is not operational.
Check the Mpcontrol.log file in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs folder.
Determine if the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Determine that a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

Check the Site Component Manager log file (sitecomp.log) in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs folder for information about other services or components that are failing or not operational on the computer hosting the MP_CONTROL_MANAGER component.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: SMS_MP_CONTROL_MANAGER is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the Configuration Manager management point control manager component within its expected interval. This can be due to high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the Mpcontrol.log file in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs folder.
Determine whether the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Determine whether a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The management point failed to register with the local WINS server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the WINS server is not running.
The IP configuration of the management point has an invalid address for the WINS server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Make sure that the WINS server on the local network is running.
Supply a valid WINS server IP address.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The management point failed to unregister from the local WINS server. Configuration Manager status message 5431 was detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The WINS server is not running.
The entry of the management point at the WINS server is missing.
Make sure that the WINS server on the local network is running.
Manually delete that management point’s entry from the WINS server.
Ignore the issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: You cannot migrate the Intel AMT provisioning information to Microsoft Configuration Manager and must take additional steps before you can manage an AMT-based computer out of band on the Configuration Manager site. These steps include the removal of AMT provisioning information and then provisioning in the Configuration Manager site.
This monitor generates the alert if it detects the clients of Configuration Manager 2007 have out of band management enabled.
Solution

maml:listItem.maml:para: Remove the AMT provisioning information of the Configuration Manager 2007 clients.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: http://technet.microsoft.com/library/gg712672.aspx#Plan_Migrate_AMT

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: To share the distribution points between Configuration Manager 2007 and Microsoft Configuration Manager you must configure a fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for the distribution points. Distribution points without a FQDN cannot be shared.
Solution

maml:listItem.maml:para: Configure a FQDN for all the distribution points of the Configuration Manager 2007 sites.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: http://technet.microsoft.com/library/gg712275#About_Shared_DPs_in_Migration

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the initial synchronization status of migration. When you specify the source site of the migration, Microsoft Configuration Manager initializes the data synchronization to establish the relationship between the source hierarchy and the destination hierarchy. This monitor generates the alert if the initialization fails.
If initialization fails, the Configuration Manager administrator cannot create a migration job. For more details, check log file: <InstallationPath>\Logs\migmctrl.log

maml:listItem.maml:para: The destination site cannot connect to the source site.
The credentials used to connect to the source site are invalid.
The credentials used to connect to the source site don’t have sufficient permissions.
Check the availability status of the source site.
Make sure the credentials used to connect to the source site are valid and have sufficient permissions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of a migration job. Migration job is used to migrate Configuration Manager objects from the source site to the destination site. There are many potential causes for failure in migration jobs.
For more details, check log file: <InstallationPath>\Logs\migmctrl.log

maml:listItem.maml:para: Most of the failures result from objects in the migration job failing to migrate. The log file provides more information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the data synchronization status of migration. After establishing the relationship between source hierarchy and the destination hierarchy, it keeps synchronize data between the two hierarchies. If data synchronization fails, the data of source hierarchy will be out-of-date, which might cause migration jobs to fail.
For more details, check log file: <InstallationPath>\Logs\migmctrl.log

maml:listItem.maml:para: The destination site cannot connect to the source site.
The credentials used to connect to the source site are invalid.
The credentials used to connect to the source site don’t have sufficient permissions.
Check the availability status of the source site.
Make sure the credentials used to connect to the source site are valid and have sufficient permissions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor identifies the Configuration Manager Device management point’s basic online status, by sending and receiving a basic HTTP request to the device management point. The component MP_CONTROL_MANAGER monitors these requests. When a device management point is online, it can accept incoming communications from mobile devices. When the device management point is offline, mobile devices cannot communicate their status, inventory, or state information to the Configuration Manager site. When the device management point is offline or in a failed state, mobile devices cannot make inquiries of the device management point to locate content such as software, and cannot locate key data or system information provided by the device management point. When a mobile device cannot communicate with the assigned device management point, it cannot be actively managed by Microsoft Configuration Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The MP_CONTROL_MANAGER component or a device management point component is not responding to HTTP requests.
A heartbeat has not been received from the device management point control manager component within its expected interval. This can be due to:
high system and Configuration Manager processing loads,
an extended wait on a request, or
a deadlock on a shared resource.
A dependent service required by the device management point is not operational.
Check the Mpcontrol.log file in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs folder.
Determine if the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Determine that a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

Check the Site Component Manager log file (sitecomp.log) in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs folder for information about other services or components that are failing or not operational on the computer hosting the MP_CONTROL_MANAGER component.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An error caused Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) synchronization to fail. The error and its source are reported in the status message. Synchronization is retried after the configured retry interval. The retry interval default is 60 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The WSUS server may not be able to connect to Windows Update.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the WSUS server is the parent WSUS server, verify that it can connect to Windows Update. On a child WSUS server verify that the parent server can be reached. Also verify that the Configuration Manager database is available and healthy.
Synchronization status can be viewed in the Configuration Manager console, under the Monitoring node. For additional details, also refer to the wsyncmgr.log.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host service has stopped. Configuration Manager requires this service to record and access necessary data. This condition does not repair itself and must be resolved before Configuration Manager can resume some of its core functions.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition typically occurs when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The client computer is shut down or is restarted.
Configuration Manager is being upgraded with Configuration Manager hotfixes or Configuration Manager service packs.
The SMS Agent Host service is manually shut down.
One of the dependent components, such as Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), is shutdown.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service was stopped due to routine or scheduled maintenance.
If the SMS Agent Host service is not already started, start it. Starting it starts all of its dependent components, such as WMI.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager generates an alert when it detects that within a specified time interval, the number of malware types that are found on a device exceeds the Multiple malware detection threshold.
To change the alert threshold

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Configuration Manager console.
Navigate to the collection and open its properties.
In the properties dialog, click the Alert tab.
Modify the Multiple malware outbreak threshold.
Configuration Manager detected that the number of malware types on a device exceed the Multiple malware detection threshold
Check the Endpoint Protection dashboard and reports in the Configuration Manager console for detailed information about the devices and the detected malware.
Remove the malware.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the component of the offer status summarizer on the site server role is not healthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following may be the cause for this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The component manager is not running.
The SMS executive service is not running.
There may be connectivity issues with the site system database server.
Check that all the components are running.
Check for environmental changes such as permissions that affect your site system servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the component of the outbox monitor is not healthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following may be the cause for this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The component manager is not running.
The SMS executive service is not running.
There may be connectivity issues with the site system database server.
There is an insufficient amount of disk space for the outbox.
There is a high volume of client status updates.
Check that all the components are running.
Check the disk space for the outboxes.
Check for environmental changes to the site.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Systems Management Server (SMS) Notification Server might become overloaded if there are more than 25,000 clients connected to it at the same time.
This counter indicates the number of clients connected to the SMS Notification Server. An alert will be generated if the number is greater than 25,000.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The processor utilization for the SMS Agent Host service on a management point has increased to 95 percent over three hours. This condition will increase unless it is resolved or until the amount of activity on the computer decreases. If this threshold is consistently exceeded, performance may suffer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The percent processor time can exceed the threshold because of insufficient processing capacity for the current SMS Agent Host tasks.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To resolve this issue and lower the percentage of processor utilization:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Add an additional processor.
Upgrade to a faster processor.
Configure additional management points in a Network Load Balancing cluster.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The backlog of collected files on the management point exceeds the threshold. The management point cannot process the information in a timely manner if this issue is not fixed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host has stopped or is not responding.
The management point file processing rate is less than the incoming rate.
The management point has insufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Verify that the threshold for this alert is not too low and is higher than the standard operating threshold for this Configuration Manager site.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it has stopped, restart the service.

Determine whether the increased load is due to an infrequent influx of new hardware inventory records, or whether the file load remains relatively constant. If the load is constant, update the Configuration Manager infrastructure to achieve zero processing backlogs. If the load is due to a large number of newly inventoried computers, the issue can resolve itself if there are sufficient resources to process pending files in addition to the standard file load.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The end point queue on the management point exceeds the threshold. The management point cannot process this information in timely manner if this issue is not fixed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host has stopped or is not responding.
The management point file processing rate is less than the incoming rate.
The management point has insufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Verify that the threshold for this alert is not too low and is higher than the standard operating threshold for this specific Configuration Manager site.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it has stopped or is not responding, restart the service.

Determine whether the increased load is due to an infrequent influx of new hardware inventory records, or whether the file load remains relatively constant. If the load is constant, update the Configuration Manager infrastructure to achieve zero processing backlogs. If the load is high due to a large number of newly inventoried computers, the issue can resolve itself if there are sufficient resources to process pending files in addition to the standard file load.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The total number of files in the discovery data record (DDR) outbox on the management point has exceeded the standard operational threshold. This condition increases unless it is resolved. If the file count exceeds the threshold, the files in this outbox will not be sent to the site server.

maml:listItem.maml:para: If the site server initiates the connection to the site system server, it could be because the SMS_Executive service is stopped or is not responding on the site server.
If the site system server initiates the connection to the site server, it could be because the SMS Agent Host on the site system server is stopped or is not responding.
The site server file processing rate is less than the incoming rate.
The site server has insufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Verify that the threshold for this alert is not too low and is beyond the standard operating threshold for this specific Configuration Manager site.
Verify that the SMS_Executive service is running on the site server. If it is stopped, restart the service.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it has stopped or is not responding, restart the service.
Verify that the Configuration Manager site database is performing properly.

maml:section.maml:para: You can check mpfdm.log for more detail information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The number of copy failures of Discover Data Record (DDR) on the management point has exceeded the standard operational threshold.

maml:listItem.maml:para: If the site system server initials the connection to the site server, it could be because the <server role> does not have permission to write to the corresponding inbox on site server.
If the site server initials the connection to the site system server it could be because the site server does not have permission to read the outbox.
The disk space of site server is insufficient
The network connection is broken.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Verify the permissions are set correctly.
Verify the site server has sufficient disk space
Verify that the site server has connectivity to the management point

maml:section.maml:para: You can check mpfdm.log for more detail information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The end point queue on management point exceeds the threshold. The management point cannot process this information in a timely manner if this issue is not fixed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host is stopped or is not responding.

The management point has insufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The end point queue on the management point exceeds the threshold. The management point cannot process this information in a timely manner if this issue is not fixed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host is stopped or is not responding.
The management point file processing rate is slower than the incoming rate.
The management point has insufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
The IIS service for the management point may not be responding.
The management point is unable to connect to its site system database server.
Verify that the threshold for this alert is not too low and is beyond the standard operating threshold for this specific Configuration Manager site.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it is stopped or is not responding, restart the service.

Determine whether the increased load is due to an infrequent influx of new hardware inventory records, or whether the file load remains relatively constant. If the load is constant, update the Configuration Manager infrastructure to achieve zero processing backlogs. If the load is due to a large number of newly inventoried computers, the issue can resolve itself if there are sufficient resources to process pending files in addition to the standard file load.
Check IIS health
Check network connectivity to the site system database server, along with certificate issues that may exist (check in the administration console database replication node under monitoring).
