maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) service. It produces an alert if the TFTP service is not available.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.
The server is not running.
WDS is not installed.
Attempt to restart the TFTP service via services.msc.
Verify WDS is installed.
Verify that the TFTP service is running under correct account.
Check WDS logs.
Verify that the TFTP server is running.
Check the TFTP windows event logs.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the service status of the Windows Deployment Service (wdsserver) service.

maml:listItem.maml:para: This monitor produces an alert if the wdsserver service is not running or missing.

This monitor is disabled by default. The ConfigMgr PXE role can use the wdsserver service OR the SccmPxe service. If this service does exist you should enable this montior and disable the SccmPxe service monitor, which is enabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The wdsserver service was stopped by an Administrator.
The wdsserver service is missing.
The wdsserver service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The wdsserver service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The wdsserver service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.
Attempt to restart the wdsserver service using services.msc.
Verify that the wdsserver service is installed. If this service is missing, disable this monitor for the ConfigMgr PXE server role, and use the SccmPxe service monitor.
Verify that the wdsserver service is running under the correct account.
Check any wdsserver logs.
Check any wdsserver windows events.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the service status of the ConfigMgr PXE Responder Service (SccmPxe) service.

maml:listItem.maml:para: This monitor produces an alert if the SccmPxe service is not running or missing.

This monitor is enabled by default. The ConfigMgr PXE role can use the wdsserver service OR the SccmPxe service. If this service does not exist you should disable this montior and enable the wdsserver service monitor, which is disabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SccmPxe service was stopped by an Administrator.
The SccmPxe service is missing.
The SccmPxe service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The SccmPxe service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The SccmPxe service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.
Attempt to restart the SccmPxe service using services.msc.
Verify that the SccmPxe service is installed. If this service is missing, disable this monitor for the ConfigMgr PXE server role, and consider enabling the wdsserver service monitor.
Verify that the SccmPxe service is running under the correct account.
Check any SccmPxe logs.
Check any SccmPxe windows events.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up the TFTP service availability to the PXE service point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager generates an alert when it detects that a type of malware is repeatedly detected on a device in a collection.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Configuration Manager repeatedly detects the same type of malware on a devices in the collection.
Check the Endpoint Protection dashboard and reports in the Configuration Manager console for detailed information about the devices and the detected malware.
Remove the malware.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager failed to load the replication component during initialization.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The replication component is not loaded correctly.
Restart the SMS Executive process for the site server to reinitialize the replication component.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager continuously monitors the health of the connectivity between parent and child Configuration Manager SQL Server databases. This confirms that replication is active across sites within a Configuration Manger hierarchy. These checks occur regularly to ensure that global data (e.g., application metadata and configuration items) is synchronized across the site server hierarchy and up the hierarchy for site data (e.g., hardware inventory).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Any number of causes will cause a failure of replication between Configuration Manger parent and child sites:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Database machine certificate is invalid.
Database service broker certificate is invalid.
SQL Port defined in configuration manager is not correct.
SQL Service Broker port is incorrect.
SQL Port is not open on the firewall.
Cannot use the specified account to connect to SQL server.
The disk space on SQL server is insufficient.
SQL Server service is down.
SQL Server service broker is down.
SMSEXEC service is down.
Network connectivity between Configuration Manager site system database servers is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: System administrators for both SQL Server and Configuration Manager as well as the network administrator should discuss options available to remedy the replication issues among Configuration Manager sites. Run the replication link analyzer from the database replication node under monitoring in the Configuration Manager administrative console for the link that is currently failed. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS_SITE_COMPONENT_MANAGER is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the SMS SITE COMPONENT MANAGER component within its expected interval. This can be caused by high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check that the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Check that a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the site component manager fails to read objects in Active Directory.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host is stopped or is not responding.
Insufficient permissions to read object in Active Directory.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it is stopped or is not responding, restart the service.
Check network connectivity to the site system database server, along with certificate issues that may exist (check in the administration console database replication node under monitoring).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager cannot create, read, update, or delete an already existing object in Active Directory. Configuration Manager status message 4912, 4913, 4915 were detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: This site server’s computer account might not have full control rights for the Configuration Manager container in Active Directory.
The Active Directory object has either been moved to a location outside of the System Management container, or it has been lost.
The Active Directory schema has not been extended with the correct Configuration Manager Active Directory classes and attributes.
Give the site server computer account full control rights to the Configuration Manager container and all child objects in Active Directory.
Delete the object from its current location, and let Configuration Manager create a new object.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager Site Component Manager could not access the site system. Configuration Manager status message 1037 was detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The site system is turned off, not connected to the network, or not functioning properly.
The Site Component Manager does not have sufficient access rights to connect to the site system.
Network problems are preventing the Site Component Manager from connecting to the site system.
You took the site system out of service and do not intend on using it as a site system any more.
Verify that the site system is turned on, connected to the network, and functioning properly.

Verify that the Site System Connection accounts are properly configured to allow Configuration Manager to connect to the site system. If the site is configured to use advanced security, then the site server's machine account must have administrator rights on the remote site system.
Investigate and correct any problems on your network.
Remove this site system from the list of site systems for this site. The list appears in the Site Systems node of the Configuration Manager console.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager cannot create, read, update, or delete an already existing object in Active Directory. Configuration Manager status message 4912, 4913, 4915 were detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: This site server’s computer account might not have full control rights for the Configuration Manager container in Active Directory.
The Active Directory object has either been moved to a location outside of the System Management container, or it has been lost.
The Active Directory schema has not been extended with the correct Configuration Manager Active Directory classes and attributes.
Give the site server computer account full control rights to the Configuration Manager container and all child objects in Active Directory.
Delete the object from its current location, and let Configuration Manager create a new object.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up the server configuration health to the ConfigMgr site.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of SMSExec process on site server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the SMS_SITE_COMPONENT_MANAGER service. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the SMS_SITE_COMPONENT_MANAGER is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service is not running.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the Windows Management Instrumentation. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the Windows Management Instrumentation service is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule generates an alert if the component of the system status summarizer on the site server role is not healthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The following may be the cause for this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The component manager is not running.
The SMS executive service is not running.
There may be connectivity issues with the site system database server.
There may be a high volume of client status updates.
There may be a high volume of discovery updates or additions.
Check that all the components are running.
Check for environmental changes such as permissions that affect your site system servers.
Check disk space availability.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the SMS_SITE_VSS_WRITER service. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the SMS_SITE_VSS_WRITER service is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service is not running.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule monitors the health state of a Configuration Manager software update point by generating a client-like, synthetic transaction. This rule indicates whether the software update point is healthy or unhealthy. If this check fails it is likely that clients cannot communicate with this server, or they have sporadic connection problems, or both.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could be caused by one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The software update point control manager is stopped or unavailable.
Configuration Manager Software Updates Point is stopped or unavailable.
Windows Software Update Services (WSUS) is stopped or non-functional.
Configuration Manager Site Server SQL Database Server is stopped, unavailable
The PXE service point is using incorrect credentials to access WSUS.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the services and configuration items previously mentioned are operating appropriately.

maml:para.maml:ui: SMS CONTROL_MANAGER maintains the value of the software update point registry key called SUPHealthState. This registry value reflects the result of a heartbeat policy or authentication request against the software update service point, which occurs once every 10 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.
This monitor is as same as the IIS Web Server service monitor of Internet Information Service management pack. If that monitor is enabled, this one can be disabled to avoid duplicated alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the IIS Web Server service (W3SVC) is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service entered a "Not Running" state.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability of Site SQL Backup Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SQL Server database instance supporting a Configuration Manager site server may have database files across multiple drives or on a single drive. The data contained in the database includes things such as application and package metadata, configuration item definitions, compliance results, and hardware and software inventory results for all clients supported by that Configuration Manager Site server.

Configuration Manager monitors the amount of free drive space across all of the drives configured to support its SQL Server database instance for the site server. Configuration Manager expects that the database minimum free disk space as configured by the Configuration Manager administrator (default thresholds: 5GB – critical; 10GB - warning) available to a site server’s SQL Server database instance exceeds the minimum configured thresholds.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The site system database server has stored more data taking up more physical disk space reducing the amount of minimum free disk space required to exceed the monitored thresholds (default thresholds: 5GB – critical; 10GB – warning).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The SQL Server database administrator needs to free up additional disk space by eliminating data in the temp DB files, shrinking database files, or allocating additional storage to the SQL Server database instance for this site. The SQL Server database administrator should work with the Configuration Manager administrator to determine the best course of action. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This is a well-defined port used for Configuration Manager replication communication between the child and parent SQL Servers using the SQL Server Service Broker (default 4022; may be customized) or between most Configuration Manager site system roles or the provider and SQL Server (default 1433; may be customized). The SQL Server port (default 1433) is maintained by the SQL Server database administrator. When setting up the SQL Server and Configuration Manager site server for the first time, the administrator of both systems and the network administrator must open the selected port in the firewall to enable proper communications between the SQL Server and the Configuration manager site system roles or the provider. Similarly, when setting up multiple SQL Server databases, each supporting a Configuration Manager site server, the SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022) must be opened in the firewall by the administrator of the SQL Servers and the network administrator.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SQL Server port (default 1433) for communications with the Configuration Manager site system roles and the provider, or the SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022) used for Configuration Manager replication communications between parent and child SQL Servers, is blocked by a firewall rule on the network or server and is preventing communication using the configured ports.
A network issue may have prevented the communication over one or both of these ports.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: When Configuration Manager detects that the configured SQL Server communications port (default 1433) or the SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022)is not able to reach the intended site system database server, the system or network, administrator needs to check for firewall port or network connectivity issues. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This is a well-defined port, used for communication between most Configuration Manager site system roles and the provider and the SQL Server (default port 1433; may be customized). Also, a well-defined port is used for communication between site system database servers through the SQL Server Service Broker (default port 4022; may be customized). The SQL Server communication port (default 1433) is maintained using the SQL Server Configuration Manager, which configures the SQL Server Network Configuration for the TCP/IP protocol. The SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022) is configured during the setup process for Configuration Manager. When setting up the SQL Server for the first time, the SQL Server database administrator performing the setup creates a particular database instance for Configuration Manager, and must choose the port on which communication occurs for that database instance.

The Configuration Manager administrator installing the site server must have local administrative permissions on the SQL Server machine to be used for the site being setup. This enables the setup program to automatically learn the correct port (default 1433) to use for configuring for setup from the named instance and set the correct port for SQL Server Service Broker (default 4022).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes

maml:listItem.maml:para: A SQL Server database Administrator has changed the TCP/IP port used to communicate with the SQL Server database instance that is configured for the Configuration Manager site server.
A SQL Server database Administrator has changed the TCP/IP port used to communicate with the SQL Server Service Broker that is configured for the Configuration Manager site system database server.

maml:section.maml:para: A firewall rule on the network is preventing communication using the configured ports.

maml:listItem.maml:para: A network issue may have prevented the communication over this port.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: When Configuration Manager detects that the SQL Server port (default 1433) configured is not able to be reached, it tries to connect to the registry on the SQL Server machine containing its database, and then changes the Configuration Manager settings to mirror the newly configured port on the SQL Server. When Configuration Manager detects that the SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022) configured is not able to be reached, it tries to connect to the SQL Server machine containing its database and changes the SQL Server Service Broker port back to its original configuration. However, if the Configuration Manager site server is unable to contact the SQL Server system, the network administrator needs to check for firewall port or network connectivity issues. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SQL Server Service Broker certificate is used to authenticate and encrypt communications between the parent and child SQL Servers. It is used for Configuration Manager replication communication between SQL Severs for the parent and child sites. When the certificate is valid, normal authenticated and encrypted communication between the SQL Servers uses this certificate. However, once the certificate is invalid, the communication between the SQL Servers is not authorized and no Configuration Manager replication can occur between the parent and child sites. The SQL Server Service Broker certificate is automatically created during installation of the site – it expires 30 years after the original creation.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The database machine certificate becomes invalid in one of several ways:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SQL Server Service Broker certificate is manually deleted from the certificate store.
The SQL Server Service Broker certificate has expired.
The SQL Server Service Broker certificate association with SQL Server login has been broken

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Manager automatically corrects this scenario by recreating a self-signed certificate. The expiration date for the newly created self-signed certificate is 30 years after the creation date. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This is a well-defined port (default 4022) used for replication communication between the child and parent SQL Servers. When installing a Configuration Manager site server, the Configuration Manager administrator performing the setup will configure a specific port for the SQL Server Service Broker port on which communication occurs between the child and parent SQL Servers. The Configuration Manager administrator installing the site server must have local administrative permissions on the SQL Server machine expected to be used for the site being set up and must know the SQL Server Service Broker port required for communication setup for its parent SQL Server Service Broker. The Configuration Manager administrator specifies this well-known port for the SQL Server service broker.

maml:listItem.maml:para: A SQL Server database Administrator has changed the TCP/IP port used to communicate with the SQL Server Service Broker that is configured for the Configuration Manager site system database server.
A firewall rule on the network is preventing communication using the configured port.
A network issue may have prevented the communication over this port.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: When Configuration Manager detects that the SQL Server Service Broker port (default 4022) configured is not able to be reached, it tries to connect to the SQL Server machine containing its database and changes the SQL Server Service Broker port back to its original configuration. . However, if the Configuration Manager site server is unable to contact the SQL Server system, the network administrator needs to check for firewall port or network connectivity issues. Check the hman.log in the [Configuration Manager Installation folder]\Logs for further information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the SQL Server VSS Writer service (SQLWriter). If you receive an alert from this monitor, action is required to bring the service back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A service can stop for many reasons, including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service was stopped by an administrator.
The service was prevented from starting because the user account could not be authenticated.
The service encountered an exception that stopped the service.
The service was improperly configured, which prevented it from starting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the SQL Server VSS Writer service is not running you can diagnose the issue or restart the service by taking the following actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check for additional service-related alerts that might have occurred concurrently. These alerts might help better identify the reason why the service is not running.
Review the event logs on the managed computer, and correct any underlying problems that might have caused the service to stop unexpectedly.
Restart the service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of Reporting Service Point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager Reporting Point service has stopped. Configuration Manager requires this service to display reports. This condition might not repair itself and must be resolved before Configuration Manager reports can be viewed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This issue typically occurs when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The reporting point computer is shut down or is restarted.

Configuration Manager is being upgraded with Configuration Manager hotfixes or Configuration Manager service packs. Configuration Manager automatically stops and restarts all necessary services during the upgrade.
The Configuration Manager Backup service runs. Configuration Manager automatically stops and restarts all necessary services when the backup task runs.
SQL Server is being upgraded with SQL Server hotfixes or SQL Server service packs or a later version of SQL Server.
The Reporting Point service is manually shut down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Reporting Point service was stopped due to routine or scheduled maintenance. If so, no action is required. If not, the reporting point has to be investigated.
Confirm that the reporting point computer is online. If the Reporting Point service is not already started, start it.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the availability status of State Migration Point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The state migration point control manager detected that the state migration point is not responding to HTTP requests.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The state migration point application pool is not configured correctly in Internet Information Services (IIS).
IIS might not be in a running state.
The firewall port is not correctly configured on the state migration point.
The Security Configuration Wizard (SCW) has not been run after the state migration point was installed.
Verify that IIS is properly configured and running.
Verify the firewall port used by the HTTP state migration point is port 80 by default.
Run the Security Configuration Wizard (SCW) after you configure the State Migration Point site role.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up the drive storage availability to the state migration point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An alert is generated if the system summary task fails.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The SMS Agent Host has stopped or is not responding.
The IIS service may not be responding.
Verify that the SMS Agent Host service is running. If it is stopped or is not responding, restart the service.
Check IIS health.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the compliance rate of a selected software update group deployment. The monitor generates the alert when the compliance rate of the selected software update group deployment is lower than the selected threshold. Use the following procedure to check or change the compliance threshold in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the compliance threshold and the current compliance rate

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Configuration Manager console.
Locate the corresponding software update group deployment and then check its deployment status.
The number of clients that failed to get the software update deployment group is larger than the selected threshold.
Check the Configuration Manager console to see which client devices did not get the software update deployment group.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the compliance rate of a specified software update deployment. The monitor generates the alert when the compliance rate of the specified software update deployment is lower than the selected threshold. Use the following procedure to check or change the compliance threshold in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the compliance threshold and the current compliance rate

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Configuration Manager console
Locate the corresponding software update deployment and then check its deployment status.
The number of clients that didn’t get the software update deployment is larger than the selected threshold .
Check the Configuration Manager console to see which clients did not get the software update deployment.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the failure rate of a an applicaton deployment. It generates the alert when the failure rate of the specified application is higher than the threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the selected threshold , open the Configuration Manager console, locate the corresponding application, and then check its deployment status.

maml:listItem.maml:para: There are a number of clients failed to deploy the specified application.
Check the Configuration Manager console to figure out which clients failed to deploy the application.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the success rate of an application deployment. It generates the alert when the success rate of the specified application is lower than the threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the selected threshold , open the Configuration Manager console, locate the corresponding application, and then check its deployment status.

maml:listItem.maml:para: There are a number of clients that failed to deploy the specified application or have not installed the specific application.
Check the Configuration Manager console to figure out which clients failed to or have not deployed the application.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the failure rate of a task sequence deployment. It generates the alert when the failure rate of the specified task sequence is higher than the threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the selected threshold , open the Configuration Manager console, locate the corresponding task sequence, and then check its deployment status.

maml:listItem.maml:para: There are a number of clients failed to deploy the specified task sequence.
Check the Configuration Manager console to figure out which clients failed to deploy the task sequence.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the success rate of a task sequence deployment. It generates the alert when the success rate of the specified task sequence is lower than the threshold, which is set in the Configuration Manager console.
To check the selected threshold , open the Configuration Manager console, locate the corresponding task sequence, and then check its deployment status.

maml:listItem.maml:para: There are a number of clients that failed to deploy the specified task sequence or have not installed the specific task sequence.
Check the Configuration Manager console to figure out which clients failed to or have not deployed the task sequence.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Wake-On-LAN Manager Component is currently unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because the component is not responding. A heartbeat has not been received from the SMS SITE COMPONENT MANAGER component within its expected interval. This can be caused by high system and Configuration Manager processing loads, an extended wait on a request, or a deadlock on a shared resource.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check that the server has sufficient resources such as CPU, memory, or disk space.
Check that a dependent component has not been stopped or uninstalled.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Configuration Manager site server and client components rely on the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server for synchronizing and scanning updates. Update Services is the host service of the WSUS server and should be running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Default Log On account for the Update Services is Network Service account. Check the Service Control Manager to ensure that it can log on.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: For more information, see the SoftwareDistribution.log under the <WSUSInstallationFolder>\LogFiles.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: WSUS_Configuration_Manager remotely configures the WSUS server from the Configuration Manager site server by using the WSUS API. After configuration it sets the state as either success or failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A compatible version of WSUS server 3.0 is not installed on the software update point.
A compatible version of WSUS 3.0 Administration console is not installed on the Configuration Manager site server.

The Internet Information Services (IIS) port information that is provided by the administrator through the software update component configuration is different than the one configured during WSUS server installation.
Network connectivity issues exist between the Configuration Manager site server and the WSUS server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuring a Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server to be used with the Configuration Manager site involves two components, the WSUS_Configuration_Manager and WSUS_Control_Manager. WSUS_Configuration_Manager sets the Configuration Manager site-specific properties that are common to all software update point role computers. WSUS_Control_Manager configures the properties that are specific to a software update point role, such as the proxy server to use or the proxy credentials to be used with the proxy server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: WSUS server is not installed on the server where you are configuring the software update point role.
An older version of WSUS server might be installed. You have to have WSUS 3.0 or later installed on the server that you want to configure as a software update point role.
This alert is raised if WSUS synchronization is running when a change of proxy server is attempted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the [ConfigMgrInstallationFolder]\Logs\WSUSCtrl.log on the specific computer that is raising this alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An error was reported during publishing of the client installation package (ccmsetup) to the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The SMS Executive process may not be running.
The WSUS Process may not be running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify that the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) process is running on the Software Update Point / WSUS server.
Verify that the SMS Executive process is running on the Configuration Manager site server.
You can get additional information about the failure by viewing the WCM.LOG file in the <ConfigMgr Install Directory>\Logs\ folder.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: WSUS_Configuration_Manager remotely configures and subscribes to categories and classifications on the Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server from the Configuration Manager site server by using the WSUS API.
Check for details in WCM.log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A compatible version of WSUS server 3.0 is not installed on the software update point.
A compatible version of WSUS 3.0 Administration console is not installed on the Configuration Manager site server.

The Internet Information Services (IIS) port information that is provided by the administrator through the software update component configuration is different than the one configured during WSUS server installation.
Network connectivity issues exist between the Configuration Manager site server and the WSUS server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: If this alert is raised, it might be because you do not have Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) server installed or because an older version of WSUS is installed on the server where you are installing the software update point role.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: WSUS server is not installed on the server where you are configuring the software update point role.
An older version of WSUS server might be installed. You have to have WSUS 3.0 or later installed on the server that you want to configure as a software update point role.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The WSUS_Control_Manager locally configures the proxy settings on the WSUS server that is installed on the Configuration Manager software update point site server by using the WSUS API. After configuration it sets the state as either success or failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition could occur because:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A compatible version of WSUS server 3.0 or WSUS server console is not installed on the software update point.
Internet Information Services (IIS) on the software update point is not functional.
Check that you have the correct version of WSUS installed on the software update point.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Represents the state of the WSUS synchronization manager component. This component is responsible for synchronizing the site software update points with the content of the Microsoft Update catalog and synchronizing the Configuration Manager database with the software update point database.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Represents the state of the Intune Dmp Downloader component.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Represents the state of the Intune Cloud User Sync component.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Represents the state of the Intune Outgoing Content Manager component.

maml:section.maml:para: For the chosen time range the x-axis will be one day. Every x-axis unit is an hour. To be able to show this histogram the values for the same hour are averaged.

maml:section.maml:para: The report can be defined using the following parameters:
Date/Time Selection: allows you to define a reporting time period using relative or fixed dates.
Business hours: allows you to set the hours and days that apply to business hours. If business hours are defined, this report will only run within the set time range.
Histogram: Allows you to select the values used for the x-axis of the report.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Daily by the hour

maml:section.maml:para: For the chosen time range the x-axis will be one day. Every x-axis unit is an hour. To be able to show this histogram the values for the same hour are averaged.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Weekly by weekdays

maml:section.maml:para: One week is the time range of the x-axis. Every unit is a weekday.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Monthly by days

maml:section.maml:para: One month is the x-axis time range. Every unit is a numeric day of the month.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Yearly by month

maml:section.maml:para: A year is the time range of the x-axis. Every unit is a month.
3D Chart: Allows choosing if the report is shown in a flat or a 3D image.
Object List: The report finds data if the object specified is of the type:

maml:listItem.maml:para: ConfigMgr Management Point
ConfigMgr Device Management Point
